review.title: Argumentation Semantics for Prioritised Default Logic
review.abstract: We endow prioritised default logic (PDL) with argumentation semantics using the ASPIC+ framework for structured argumentation, and prove that the conclusions of the justified arguments are exactly the prioritised default extensions. Argumentation semantics for PDL will allow for the application of argument game proof theories to the process of inference in PDL, making the reasons for accepting a conclusion transparent and the inference process more intuitive. This also opens up the possibility for argumentation-based distributed reasoning and communication amongst agents with PDL representations of mental attitudes.

sections.heading: 4.4 Summary
sections.text: In this section, we provided an instantiation from ASPIC + to PDL. We can construct an ASPIC + attack graph from an LPDT. Subtlety then consists in finding a suitable argument preference relationship so that it matches the conclusions of the justified arguments and the extensions of the PDT. We showed that none of the ASPIC + commands results in a match, and even the intuitive disjunctive elite order does not match. Then, we developed the structure preference sequence, which mimics how defaults in PDL are added when constructing extensions. We then showed that ASPIC + defense graphs constructed by LPDTs have unique stable extensions. The representation theorem states that under the structure preference sequence the conclusions exactly match - this is a result of solidity and completeness.
